segments.text: It's been suggested that during this period while you were at the Hydrographic Office that research and development oceanography was directed by or divided up, if I may use that word, between Ewing, Islin, and Revell, that they sort of are working on plotting, as it were, expanding oceanography.
Would you agree with that?
You're talking...
I'm talking about 46, 47, and 48, when Scripps and Woods Hole and O&R began to think about what the future of oceanography is.
Yes, I think that's probably a pretty fair statement.
They certainly exerted a lot of influence in the Washington area.
And I think it's hard in a way for me to recall too much what was happening at the institutions at that time, because I wasn't there.
I wasn't in any of them.
I was in Washington.
I think it was really to kind of stabilize after the war and get things on what was looked at as more or less stable footing.
There was, if I can go off on a tangent here for a moment, I showed you this morning this book by Vaughan, which is
I have called NASCO one.

NASCO is a term that came in later, but this was one of the early attempts of the National Academy of Sciences to look at the state of marine sciences in this country, which occurred in the 1920s, although that book of lawns was not published until essentially 10 years later.

But there was another National Academy committee set up at about the time you're talking about, and I can't remember it exactly, at which Scripps, Woods Hole, and so on were asked essentially what they thought they wanted to do.
And I can't recall any of the content, but there is a small publication resulting from that committee

The only part of it I can recall at all was that Professor Thompson, who was then director of what were known as the Oceanographic Laboratories at the University of Washington, his chief emphasis that he just wanted to return to the pre-war status, which I thought was singularly unimaginative, as I remember.
But yes, I think that...
It was pretty much dominated by Woods Hole scripts, and then Lamont came on the scene, I guess, about that time.
And then there was this flurry of establishment of essentially new laboratories, Chesapeake Bay Institute, Texas A&M in particular come to mind here, and there were several others, as I recall.
What sort of fellow was Islin?
What was he like?

Well, I think I, although I was never sort of spent very much time at Woods Hole and so on, apparently I knew more about him than a lot of his people that more or less lived with him, in that he was very much sort of a lone wolf in a way, although he was quite
outgoing in meetings and conferences and so on.
His private life was something which was very much his own, and he lived on Martha's Vineyard, and later on near Boston, I think it was in Newton.
I'm one of the few people who's ever been a house guest at the Estlunds as far as I know, and I don't know quite why.
He was a real sort of a puzzle to me, in a way, because he was very imaginative in many ways, and very farsighted in looking ahead and so on.
In fact, I was just thinking the other day that some of the things he said to me,
at the time I thought were silly, and which I now look back on and see that he was just about 10 or 20 years ahead of anybody else and things.
However, I always felt that he was in a sense anti-intellectual, which sounds kind of snobbish here, but his own background was only, I think, up to
level of a bachelor's degree.
And his degree, I think, was actually in anthropology.
In other words, he didn't have a very strong sort of scientific background on which to build.
And he tended to look for similar types of people, in many cases, who were interested but
I would consider, in a sense, not scientifically qualified.
Now, he made me a liar in a number of cases here, in that some of these people that he had joined the Woodso organization have turned out to be very outstanding.
But I would venture that this, out of general average, was not too good.

And one of the great deficiencies I felt at Woods Hole was that they never sincerely sought, I'm talking of the era when Islin was there, but it tended to carry on after he'd retired, was that they never really supported an educational program either at Woods Hole or anywhere else.
They were very, very much sort of research-oriented here.
And it was only when...
I think it was Admiral Smith in particular later on saw certain advantages which could be achieved in terms of money by becoming an educational institution.
They sort of switched in that direction, but I don't think they've ever really taken it very seriously.
That's my sort of point here.
So I asked Columbus one day, how do you recruit your people?
And he said, oh, I don't worry about that.
I have enough nice young men come knocking on my door.
I never have to go looking for people.
And I think this was true in many cases.
They were nice young men, in the best sense of the word.
What about Ewing?
Oh, Ewing is an entrepreneur, obviously, and very aggressive, very different, and entirely different from Islin, with a very tremendously hardworking and broadly interested and very much
the entrepreneur, as I said, capable of interesting people, raising money, getting things going, and so on.
I think with a good eye in most cases for people that he hired to work with him, the main sort of reservation I have about
Ewing, as I used to identify him, he was a cream skimmer.

He'd get an idea, do enough work on it to sort of meet his particular interest at the moment, sometimes correctly, sometimes, I think, misinterpreting things, and then he'd move on to something else and leave it to other people to kind of come along and clean up
Sometimes the mess, I think, he left behind him, in a sense.
But I think we can, in a field such as this, we can always and should consider ourselves fortunate to have some people like that.
We don't want everybody to be Morris Ewing.
That same charge has been leveled against Revell.
Would you agree with that?
Well, Revell has switched around a great deal.
And yet I think, again, it's hard to make offhand kind of judgments and evaluations, but his interests were clearly much broader than Ewing's.
And I think it's fair to say that Ravel had, in a sense, an altruistic interest in many of these things, although they redounded to his glory in a way.
But I think Ewing's concerns were always, as things affected Ewing.
And I can't imagine Ewing getting involved in these programs in India and so on, Pakistan, as Ravel did, or
or Ewing going to Harvard, as Ravel did, and entering an entirely new set of fields here.
And so there's really some very major differences, I think, between them.
Now, it's almost as if in, let's say, about 48 or 49, right before you decide to come to Washington, it's almost as if the ONR says,

look, there's not enough oceanographers to suit the needs, and what we've got to do is move out and not only establish departments of oceanography, but establish particular kinds of departments of oceanography.
We need, for example, chemical oceanographers, and where should that be and what should it be?
We need people to work on the Gulf Coast, and what should they do and what should they be?
Would you agree with that?
Yes, I think my, I haven't thought about,
these things for so long, and dates and events and so on are getting confused.
But there was this sort of regionalism, yes, that we ought to spot places in appropriate coastal regions.
And there was nothing in the Gulf of Mexico and so on.

And then this Chesapeake Bay development came up, which was really, I think, possibly brought into being as much as anything else by the fact that ONR was willing to put some money into it, although it was, as I recall, sort of a tripartite arrangement at first of Maryland, Virginia, and ONR.
And that was thought of as a center for sort of looking at large bays and estuaries, and so it was partly regional, partly sort of subject matter.
I don't really recall any
a strong impetus really towards sort of training programs, although they obviously came along with this in a way.
ONR is always in the rather difficult position that they were not supposed to support education as such.
And so it was often done, but it was budgeted for in essentially other terms here.
They certainly wanted to help here, and Dr. Thompson was the director of what were then known as the Oceanographic Laboratories, which had existed since about 1930 when the Rockefeller
money was available, and the laboratories were set up.
And there was some teaching prior to the war, some local sort of work at sea with a very small vessel which was actually sold by the university during the war.
So there was no vessel left here.
When Dr. Thompson came back to the university,

after the war he'd been in he had a commission in the chemical warfare branch of the army he tried to pick up the pieces and sort of re-establish a program here and found it very difficult because a lot of the people had moved away or died or got other interests there was no vessel here and so on so he was really faced with a

real problem, and the first thing that essentially the ONR did here was provide a little money to essentially get a small vessel going again and to support a few people and, you know, as I indicated a while ago, kind of get it going a little bit as it had been

ten years previously and so when I came out here ONR support was about a hundred thousand dollars a year and that was essentially the only support available and it was available on a it's really kind of block funding and it was out of this we began to develop the programs here so
Yes, I think it was a deliberate effort of ONR to try and proliferate.
But I think in many cases, if the availability of funds for some of these newer institutions and trying to get the University of Washington back in business again
was essentially as long as it didn't interfere too much with the funding of Scripps and Woods Hole, which may sound like sour grapes, but I think that in a way this was a sort of situation.
Who made contact with you to come out here?
I don't know exactly what happened, but the man on the faculty or the administration here
contacted me was the dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, Dean Lloyd Woodburn.
And I don't know whether I'd been suggested by Tommy Thompson or just have, but they had realized, and I think this is sort of worth noting, that they couldn't go back to the kind of pre-war
operations, that something had to be done here that would change the thing.

And in the spring of 1951, the Board of Regents, which is our governing body, decided, I'm sure it was on the recommendation of Dean Woodburn, to create a Department of Oceanography in the College of Arts and Sciences.

which then just changed the emphasis away from sort of a research activity towards an educational activity and made it entirely appropriate to go into sort of undergraduate as well as graduate education.
There were two sort of separate entities here at the university which had been operated before the war and had returned to this sort of
the situation after the war, both of them operated under this general title of the Oceanographic Laboratories, plural.
And one was a facility at the Friday Harbor on the San Juan Islands, which is a field station type thing.
And the building that had been erected on the main campus here, which with Rockville
here is hidden by the other edifice here now.
These two things were operated jointly under Professor Thompson.
And when I came out here, the assumption was that I would operate both of them.
But for a variety of reasons, it seemed much better to me to operate them separately.
But I was not only, I was called executive officer
Department of Oceanography and director of the Friday Harbor Laboratories.
And I had two jobs, in effect, for some seven years, I think it was.
And then someone else took over as director at the Friday Harbor Laboratories.
But I had dual sort of jobs here.
mentioned earlier I got into sort of administration of one kind during the war, administration of kind of another kind in Washington.
I came out here and I got into still another kind of administration.
So in many respects I haven't been a research scientist for a long, long time here and it was more by accident than I think by choice.
When you came
to the west to visit the dean, what did he tell you?
What about the Department of Oceanography he wanted you to find?
Oh, I think that I had fairly strong ideas at that time about what I thought I wanted to do.
And part of it had come out of some
deliberations that had gone on, and I can't really remember at the moment who prompted them, whether it was ONR or some other agency.
We had a number of meetings on essentially education in oceanography, and there was a paper

was finally published, and I think it was in Science, if I remember correctly, by Redfield and I think Revell and several others, sort of setting out what they felt the curriculum in oceanography ought to be.
And this was part of what I sort of had in mind when I came out here.
In other words, I wasn't operating entirely on my own hunches here.
There was some

agreement in a sense as to what might be done now that what was different here was the opportunity to get into the undergraduate program and this it took us about a year I think to develop a sort of program of courses and so forth that we thought we could

start with and and we had our first students i guess in in about 1952 now uh this is in effect now the first institution of undergraduate oceanography in the country and possibly in the world uh so what sort of students did you look for
Well, I don't know whether we looked for a particular kind of students, because students kind of come to you in a case like this.
What we felt, and I think correctly, was that we were offering them a sort of an interesting field, but more particularly, an opportunity for students.
obviously science-oriented, and in a sense here, basically science-oriented, a basic science orientation.
A field where the student could be a kind of a scientific generalist rather than a specialist
And I've always felt that way, and I feel it even more so today, that I'm not saying it's the kind of program that should be available for everybody or it really shouldn't displace
the kind of specialist programs.
But I think there should be opportunities at all levels for students who have an inclination towards being broad, being generalists, interdisciplinary, and these other terms that are used.
There should be some opportunities for that.
And this is essentially what we started out with this in mind.
The other sort of things we had in mind was to prepare
people really for jobs in agencies such as hydrographic office and other government and state agencies who needed people.

The other institutions at that time were all post graduate and really all they were interested in were doctoral people so they were training all the generals but they didn't have any Indians to go along with them and I felt that
not very glamorous, but certainly a need that I thought we could meet, and I think we did fairly well.
The original sort of concept was that all the students would go through a similar sort of curriculum, but this only lasted for a relatively few years, and then
we began increasing in numbers, and the research programming increased, and there were more faculty, and so forth.

And I found I was essentially fighting a losing battle here, because all of the options, as we used to call them in the department, physical, chemical, biological, geological, and somewhat more recently geophysical, all wanted to have their own sort of program
So this idea of a kind of a basic common undergraduate preparation gave way to, again, more specialized optional programs in these sort of five fields.
And I got sort of out of sorts with this as the years went by.
a swing in the other direction now, and they're beginning to feel that maybe there is some merit to having people who set abroad training again.
But it's taken 20 years or so for the pendulum to swing, and it hasn't moved very far in that direction.
When you started choosing faculty, what sort of faculty did you look for?
Well, this is more or less, you know, kind of parallel to the students, so there's no one to look for.

When I came out here, Professor Thompson, who was a chemist and chemical oceanographer, Cliff Barnes, who was originally a chemist but more so a physical oceanographer, Morris Rattray, who had come in just finishing his PhD from Caltech, who was a theoretical hydrodynamicist,
and myself.
I think that was about it.
We had really nobody in the geological area, nobody in the biological area, and so part of my job was to obviously try and find some people in these two sort of fields, and it turned out
be just as hard as it had been during the war and back in the Hydrographic Office to find anybody to go into these areas.
The first geological oceanographer I was able to add to the faculty was Howard Gould, who's now and has been for a number of years with the
Humble Research Laboratories in Houston.
And he spent several years with us and then felt he wanted more money and so on, so he went to Humble.
And the next geologist I recruited was Joe Krager, who was a brand new PhD out of Texas A&M.
He was one of the very first of the PhDs.
But these people had
very little sort of experience themselves.
I mean, they were, as the most recent PhDs, and they had to, in a sense, learn a lot on the job here.
Not as far as this sort of research, I'm not saying that, but from a teaching point of view.
The biologists turned out to be almost equally hard to find anybody who was not strictly a sort of a biologist, but had some of the interests of what I would
identify as a biological oceanographer, which meant some other background.
This turned out to be just as hard to find anybody there.
This has more or less persisted, I think, even up to today.
One of the things that strikes me all the time is that you can
clearly fine research people these days.
Often, however, with really very narrow kind of preparation, but very few of them with any kind of teaching experience.
Now, maybe one of our contributions here has been the fact that an awful lot of graduate students have been teaching assistants here, a kind of experience they never got in any of the other places.
and do go out of here, not all of them, but a good many of them, with some kind of feeling about what the teaching job is.
How are you doing?
